description.p: A top the highest tower, swords clash. The half-elf is poised with his rapier held steady and his free hand tucked behind his back. As his half-orc opponent swings, he sidesteps effortlessly before landing a stab in her shoulder. She drops her axe, clutches her wounds, and reluctantly concedes her defeat.

There is a commotion in the streets. A fight has broken out between two opposing merchants. An officer draped in formal regalia pushes through the crowd as he draws his saber. With a booming voice, he demands an end to the disturbance. His authority alone is enough to end the fight.

Cannons fire. Sparks and splinters fly. As the ships collide, the pirate captain swings aboard the enemy vessel to take his prize. He dispatches two of the privateers with his throwing daggers before drawing his cutlass. If they surrender, he just might offer some of them a place on his crew.
Buccaneers are many things. Polite, but bold. Cunning, but charming. Daring, but civilized. Fascinating, but deadly.

What distinguishes a buccaneer from a common fighter? Presentation. A buccaneer's wits are just as sharp as their blades, and they are as fierce as they are charming. Buccaneers are always looking to hone their swordplay techniques. As such, they fight defensively, allowing their opponent to reveal their hand before going in for the kill. They favor precise cuts and counters over sheer force.

Buccaneers live by honor codes that determine how they bear themselves both on and off the battlefield. These codes are composed of various virtues and values, this does not mean that all buccaneers are benevolent. After all, loyalty is a virtue, even if it means loyalty to your pirate crew.

Whether they're aiming to become a renowned general or a pirate king, a buccaneer is always ambitious. To this end, they will cultivate an air of sophistication and magnetism that allows them to flourish amongst high society.

Your relationship with swordplay is an important part of your identity as a buccaneer. How were you trained with a blade? Did you enlist in a military unit? Were you trained by a wandering duelist who saved your town?
Next, you must define your goal. Buccaneers are ambitious, and always have their sights set on their long-term objectives. Do you seek fortune? Fame? Renown? Infamy?

You can make a buccaneer quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Dexterity, and your next highest into Charisma. Second, choose the soldier or pirate background.
As an buccaneer, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d10 per buccaneer level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per buccaneer level after 1st
Armor: Light armor, Medium armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, rapiers, scimitars, shortswords, whips, hand crossbows, heavy crossbows
Tools: One gaming set of your choice
Saving Throws: Dexterity, Charisma
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Deception, Intimidation, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a rapier or (b) two scimitars
(a)leather armor or (b) scale mail
(a) a diplomat's pack or (b) an explorer's pack
one gaming set you are proficient with
a feathered hat, a fancy doublet, and a shoulder cape

description.p: Crossing swords with you is like a deadly game of chess. Whenever a creature misses you with a melee attack during their turn, you can use a reaction to target them with a melee attack using a finesse weapon. You cannot make this attack while wearing heavy armor or wielding a shield.

sheet.description: Whenever a creature misses you with a melee attack during their turn, you can use a reaction to target them with a melee attack using a finesse weapon. You cannot make this attack while wearing heavy armor or wielding a shield.

description.p: You count on being able to outmaneuver your opponents. During your turn, if you target a creature with a melee attack using a finesse weapon, that creature can’t make opportunity attacks against you for the rest of your turn.

sheet.description: You count on being able to outmaneuver your opponents. During your turn, if you target a creature with a melee attack using a finesse weapon, that creature can’t make opportunity attacks against you for the rest of your turn.

description.p: What's swordplay without a little wordplay? At 2nd level, you can use a bonus action to attack a creature's pride, forcing them to make a Charisma saving throw against your fencing save DC. The creature must be able to see or hear you.

On a failed save, the creature has disadvantage on its next attack roll that does not target you, and will take an additional 1d4 damage the next time you hit it with a finesse weapon. This die increases as you gain buccaneer levels, as shown in the Fencing column of the Buccaneer Table.

center.p: Fencing save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier

sheet.description: Your Fencing save DC is {{fencing:dc}}. You can use a bonus action to attack a creature's pride, forcing them to make a Charisma saving throw against your fencing save DC. The creature must be able to see or hear you. description.p: Also at 2nd level, you adopt one of the following styles of fighting as your specialty. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.
You gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with weapons you wield in one hand while wielding no other weapons.
You can draw a weapon that has the thrown property as part of the attack you make with the weapon.
In addition, when you hit with a ranged attack using a thrown weapon, you gain a +2 bonus to the damage roll.
When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

At 3rd level, you choose a set of ideals to uphold as a buccaneer. Choose the Duelist, Officer, Pirate, Spellsword, Treasure Hunter, or Musketeer code, all detailed at the end of the class description. Your code grants features at 3rd level and again at 9th, 13th, and 18th level.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: Also at 5th level, thanks to your vgilante technique, hostile creatures provoke a Counter-Attack from you after they target a creature other than you with a melee attack.

sheet.description: Hostile creatures provoke a Counter-Attack from you after they target a creature other than you with a melee attack.

description.p: At 6th level, choose two of your skill proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

At 7th level, while you are not wearing heavy armor and are not wielding a shield, you gain a +1 bonus to your AC. When you hit a creature with an attack using a finesse weapon, this bonus increases by 1, up to a maximum bonus equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum bonus of +1). This bonus resets to +1 whenever you take damage or roll for initiative.

When you hit a creature with an attack using a finesse weapon, this bonus increases by 1, up to a maximum bonus equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum bonus of +1). This bonus resets to +1 whenever you take damage or roll for initiative.

description.p: By 10th level, you are rather fond of adding insult to injury. Once per turn after you deal damage to a creature with an attack using a finesse weapon, you can target that creature with your Banter as part of the same attack.

sheet.description: Once per turn after you deal damage to a creature with an attack using a finesse weapon, you can target that creature with your Banter as part of the same attack.

description.p: At 11th level, your precision with a blade is so fine-tuned that all of your attacks with finesse weapons deal additional damage equal to a roll of your Fencing die. Additionally, you can use your Fencing die in place of the normal damage die for any finesse weapon.

sheet.description: Your attacks with finesse weapons deal additional damage equal to a roll of your Fencing die. Additionally, you can use your Fencing die in place of the normal damage die for any finesse weapon.

description.p: By 14th level, your overbearing confidence in the face of a challenge makes you immune to the frightened condition. Creatures provoke a Counter-Attack from you whenever they attempt to frighten you.

sheet.description: Your overbearing confidence in the face of a challenge makes you immune to the frightened condition. Creatures provoke a Counter-Attack from you whenever they attempt to frighten you.

description.p: At 15th level, your persona is larger than life. If you hold a pleasant conversation with a non-hostile creature for 10 minutes, they become charmed by you for 1 hour, or until you or your allies do anything harmful to it. Once you charm a creature this way, you cannot charm them with this feature again until you complete a long rest.

description.p: By 17th level, you can make the most of any opening. If you score a critical hit against a creature that is not incapacitated with a melee attack using a finesse weapon, you can target them with another melee attack using that weapon.

description.p: At 20th level, people tell tales and sing songs of your famous duels and your dramatic exploits. Your Dexterity and Charisma scores each increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

sheet.description: Your Dexterity and Charisma scores each increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

description.p: An honorable duelist values courage, respect, and integrity. They will gladly stake their life on their honor, and tend to do so regularly. They are proud and boisterous warriors.
When you choose this code at 3rd level, your approach to combat is as traditional as it is effective. You can assume battle stances, each with its own benefits and drawbacks.

At 3rd level, you learn two stances of your choice from the options listed below. You learn an additional stance at 9th, 13th, and 18th level in this class. You can only be in one stance at a time. You can use a bonus action to enter a stance you know, switch to a different stance you know, or exit your stance entirely. You cannot benefit from a stance while you are incapacitated, are wearing medium or heavy armor, are wielding a shield, or are not wielding a finesse weapon.

ul.li: Aegis. You gain +2 AC, but you gain disadvantage on attack rolls.
Blitz. You add your proficiency bonus to damage rolls for melee attacks with finesse weapons, but you have -2 AC.
Focus. You gain advantage on Counter-Attacks, but you gain disadvantage on attacks of opportunity.
Gash. You score a critical hit with melee attacks on a roll of 19 or 20, but you have disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
Notch. Creatures provoke an opportunity attack from you when they enter the reach of a finesse melee weapon you are wielding, but your movement speed is halved.

This extends to other unstable positions where you might have disadvantage on attack rolls, such as walking on a tightrope, or backpedaling on a staircase.

Your initiative becomes the creature's initiative +1. You can only target the chosen creature with attacks or spells during your first turn in combat.

description.p: Starting at 18th level, you can predict your opponent's attacks before they strike, allowing you to use a reaction to target a creature with a Counter-Attack the moment that they target you with a melee attack. If your Counter-Attack lands, the creature's attack misses automatically.

description.p: Officers are instilled with the values of trust, discipline, and structure. Before resorting to violence, they will attempt to pacify their foes if possible. They are attentive, efficient, confident, and reliable: all the traits of a natural leader.

When you choose this code at 3rd level, you seek to end conflicts without bloodshed when possible. Whenever you make a Counter-Attack, you can strike the target using the pommel of your weapon, causing the attack to deal bludgeoning damage.

When you hit a creature with this kind of Counter-Attack, they must make a Dexterity saving throw against your fencing save DC. On a failed save, the creature becomes stunned until the end of their turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses of it whenever you complete a short or long rest.

Furthermore, you can read others as though they were an open book, allowing you to add your Charisma modifier to any Wisdom (Insight) check you make.

description.p: By 9th level, you can maneuver through combat with ease. Whenever a creature misses you with a melee attack during their turn, you can move 5 feet without provoking opportunity attacks from that creature. You can use this movement either become or after making a Counter-Attack.

description.p: Starting at 13th level, your disciplined technique allows you to ruthlessly punish your enemy's mistakes. You automatically score a critical hit with your Counter-Attack if the target rolled a 1 on the triggering attack roll. Furthermore, the creature has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes before the end of your next turn.

sheet.description: You automatically score a critical hit with your Counter-Attack if the target rolled a 1 on the triggering attack roll. Furthermore, the creature has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes before the end of your next turn.

description.p: At 18th level, you can give your opponents a chance to back away before things get ugly. Whenever you roll for initiative, you can give a number of creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) that you can see within 60 feet of you a chance to leave combat before it even begins.

You can target each creature that refuses to surrender with your Banter. When you use your Banter this way, creatures that fail the saving throw against it must roll their initiative with disadvantage, and they cannot end the effects of your Banter by damaging you.
Creatures that cannot see or hear you are unaffected by this feature. You also cannot use this feature if you are surprised.
Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

description.p: The pirate code is defined by liberty, autonomy, and loyalty to one's crew. All a pirate truly wants is to be beholden to no lord or king. They'll fight tooth and nail to live free.

When you choose this manifestation at 3rd level, you take to combat like a shark to blood in the water. Whenever you hit a creature with a melee attack using a finesse weapon, you can attempt to damage another creature with the same attack. Choose another creature within 5 feet of the original target and within your reach. If the original attack roll would hit the second creature, it takes damage equal to a roll of your Fencing die. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack.

Choose another creature within 5 feet of the original target and within your reach. If the original attack roll would hit the second creature, it takes damage equal to a roll of your Fencing die. The damage is of the same type dealt by the original attack.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with water vehicles and Navigator's Tools if you don't have them already, and can determine which way is north by examining the stars on your home plane of existence.

sheet.description: You can determine which way is north by examining the stars on your home plane of existence.

description.p: At 9th level, you can cast Find Familiar at will to summon a parrot. The parrot's stats are the same as those of a raven, but the parrot has a superior form of the raven's Mimicry, as it can perfectly mimic any sound it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds of your parrot can tell they are imitations if they succeed a Wisdom saving throw against your fencing save DC. The parrot has also been trained as a lookout, giving it a passive perception of 15 plus your Charisma modifier (minimum of 16 passive perception).

description.p: At 13th level, you're never so foolish as to be caught unarmed. Whenever you roll initiative while wearing armor, you gain a number of daggers equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1). These daggers are stowed on your person in hidden compartments throughout your armor, such as up your sleave or in your boot. You can draw one of these daggers as part of a Counter-Attack you make with it, causing the Counter-Attack to be made with advantage. These daggers are lost at the end of combat.

description.p: At 18th level, whenever you hit a creature with a Counter-Attack, you can force them to make a Dexterity saving throw against your fencing save DC if they are within 5 feet of you and no more than one size larger than you. On a failed save, you hold your weapon within an inch of the creature's vitals, causing them to be grappled by you.

To escape this grapple, the creature must make another Dexterity saving throw against your fencing save DC as an action on their turn. On a successful save, the creature escapes the grapple. On a failed save, you can target the creature with a Counter-Attack without expending a reaction.
Your movement speed is not halved due to this grapple, allowing you to easily force the creature into hazards they would normally avoid, such as off of a high ledge or into a blazing inferno.

description.p: A spellsword values ingenuity, innovation, and the pursuit of knowledge for its own sake. They are chosen for their innate arcane talent and then taught to wield blades.

When you choose this code at 3rd level, you unlock innate magical abilities that you use to enhance your combat techniques. You have a number of spellsword points equal to half of your buccaneer level, rounded up. These points can be spent to perform martial metamagic. You regain all expended spellsword points once you complete a short or long rest. You learn 2 martial metamagic options, detailed under "Martial Metamagic" below. You learn an additional option at 9th, 13th, and 18th buccaneer level.
When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the martial metamagic options you know and replace it with another martial metamagic option.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, you can use a bonus action to summon a melee weapon that you made an attack with on your last turn back to your hands instantly if you are no longer holding it.

Regardless of what set of tools you choose, you use Charisma as your ability modifier when performing checks with tools affected by this ability. Once you use this ability, you must complete a short or long rest to use it again.

You can continue walking in the air with this ability as if you were on the ground, and will only begin falling at the end of your next turn. Conversely, you can use this ability to descend the staircase, being lowered 5 feet for every 10 feet you walk.

description.p: In a line of business where it's easy to get double-crossed, treasure hunters live by the code of honor amongst thieves. Ancient artifacts, lost expeditions, and hidden troves fascinate them. Just don't cut them out of a deal.

When you choose this code at 3rd level, by all rights, something ought to have killed you by now. Whenever you end your turn without having targeted any creatures with attacks, spells, or harmful effects, you automatically gain the benefits of the Dodge action, and gain advantage on any Counter-Attack you make before the start of your next turn.

Additionally, you have a knack for making the best of a bad situation. Whenever you roll a 1 on a melee attack roll with a finesse weapon, you can still deal damage equal to a roll of your Fencing die to the target.

Additionally, you have a knack for making the best of a bad situation. Whenever you roll a 1 on a melee attack roll with a finesse weapon, you can still deal damage equal to a roll of your Fencing die to the target.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, exploring the far corners of the world requires you to be ready for anything. You gain proficiency with Cartographer's Tools if you did not have it already. Additionally, while you are not wearing heavy armor, you gain a climbing and swimming speed of 20 feet.

sheet.description: While you are not wearing heavy armor, you gain a climbing and swimming speed of 20 feet.

description.p: At 9th level, you excel at unearthing secrets and mysteries considered lost to the sands of time. You can add your Charisma modifier to any Intelligence (Investigation) or Intelligence (History) check you make.

Additionally, you are familiar with most languages, even if you haven't studied them extensively. You can identify what language a piece of writing is in, even if you do not know how to read or speak that language.
If you rack your brain, you can come up with translations for languages on the fly. You can make a DC 10 Intelligence (History) check to become proficient with a language of your choice for 1 minute.
Each time that you attempt this Intelligence check after the first, the DC for the check increases by 5. Once you complete a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

description.p: At 13th level, you aren't afraid to fight dirty when you have to. You can make a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check instead of a Strength (Athletics) check when attempting to grapple or shove a creature. This represents moves that deftly throw the target off balance without overpowering them, such as knocking a creature prone by tripping them with your foot or grappling a creature by twisting their arm behind their back.
Additionally, after you hit a creature with a Counter-Attack, you attempt to grapple or shove the creature as part of the same reaction if they are within 5 feet of you.

description.p: Starting at 18th level, you know that it's all in the timing. If you end your turn without having targeted any creatures with attacks, spells, or harmful effects, then you can regain your reaction whenever you successfully land a Counter-Attack until the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: If you end your turn without having targeted any creatures with attacks, spells, or harmful effects, then you can regain your reaction whenever you successfully land a Counter-Attack until the start of your next turn.

description.p: For a musketeer, a sword is just a side-arm. Their code demands that they be polite, efficient, and have a plan to kill everyone they meet... just in case.

When you choose this code at 3rd level, your experience with ballistic weapons grants you proficiency with the renaissance firearms described in chapter 9 of the Dungeon Master's Guide. Additionally, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: Bayonet. You can treat renaissance firearms as finesse melee weapons that deal 1d6 piercing damage. When used as melee weapons, pistols have the light property, and muskets have the reach property.
One-Liner. If a creature fails the saving throw against your Banter, you gain advantage on the next ranged attack you make against them before the end of your next turn.
Quickdraw. Whenever you draw or stow a weapon, you can draw or stow a renaissance firearm as well.

If a creature fails the saving throw against your Banter, you gain advantage on the next ranged attack you make against them before the end of your next turn.

description.p: Also at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with Tinkerer's Tools if you didn't have it already. By investing time and money, you can use Tinkerer's Tools to craft firearms.

div.p: At the discretion of the DM, the Bullets, Pistols, and Muskets that this Code of Virtue uses can be exchanged for Crossbow bolts, Light Crossbows, and Heavy Crossbows respectively.

sheet.description: You can use Tinkerer's Tools to craft firearms.

description.p: At 9th level, you can ricochet bullets between your enemies. If you have advantage on a ranged attack you make with a renaissance firearm, you can choose to forgo that advantage. If you still hit your target, you can make another ranged attack with the same weapon against a new target within 30 feet of the initial target. You can ignore the weapon's loading property for this secondary attack.

If you still hit your target, you can make another ranged attack with the same weapon against a new target within 30 feet of the initial target. description.p: At 13th level, you can fire back at your enemies with ranged Counter-Attacks using renaissance firearms. Creatures provoke a ranged Counter-Attack from you when they miss you with a ranged attack.

description.p: At 18th level, you can pack your firearms full of deadly shrapnel. As an action on your turn, you can target each creature within a 20 foot cone in front of you with an attack using a renaissance firearm you are wielding. You can ignore the weapons's loading property for each attack after the first.
